channel.title: Gdnbloggers on Forest Garden Wales
channel.description: Recent content in Gdnbloggers on Forest Garden Wales
channel.copyright: This work is dual-licensed under MIT & GPL v3

item.title: Recycled ever-expanding plant labels
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I used to tie ordinary plants to tree branches with bits of baling twine.

item.title: How to establish ground cover in a forest garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: A key principle of no-dig gardening is to always protect the soil with mulch.

item.title: Forest garden plan
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: This is the latest version of the forest garden plan for what is unaffectionately known as Forest Garden One (I had a mental block with names that day).

item.title: Ornamental Forest Garden plan
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: The Ornamental Forest Garden (OFG) plan is based on a satellite photo, so it should be more accurate than the Forest Garden One, which is based on a digital Ordnance Survey map.

item.title: Dead hedging in the forest garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I’ve just found out about the benefits of a dead hedge from Janie who came on the forest garden workshop.

item.title: Why a forest garden is good for climate change
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Climate change is caused by living in an unsustainable way. Forest gardens by definition are a sustainable and sustaining form of gardening.

item.title: Forest garden itinerary
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: We had our first forest garden tour and workshop last week, via Airbnb.

item.title: Creating a simple propagation bed
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: At the beginning of any forest garden project, I always recommend surveying and planning first, followed by propagating ground cover plants.

item.title: Easy graft
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: A couple of months ago, I went on a grafting workshop run by Steve Wilson and organised by The People’s Orchard.

item.title: Splashes of colour in a sea of shimmering green
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I like forest gardens, obviously. Although they can be very… green. In the midst of this wintry spell here in West Wales, I’ve sown some flowers, pollinator friendly flowers, that will also add a zing of colour to the borders.

item.title: Gardening in the vernacular
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Long before I stumbled into forest gardening, I always loved allotments. My parents had one, with chickens and runner beans, hot sun and fresh peas.

item.title: Tree spacing in the forest garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: It’s important to leave enough space between trees in the canopy layer, so that there’s enough light coming through to the plants below.

item.title: Designing a small forest garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I really think that your small garden can be a forest garden, because to be a forest garden is more abut the principles than the size.

item.title: Flowers for pollinators in an orchard
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Steve Wilson, the tutor at a recent People’s Orchard grafting workshop, discussed how his wildflower meadow encourages pollinators.

item.title: Our forest garden tours & workshops setup
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I’ve organised the forest garden tours and workshops for 2019. I decided to market them as Airbnb holiday Experiences because it is a vast amount of work to manage an online shop, calendar and publicity.

item.title: Leave space
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: We’ve planted the canopy layer in the Ornamental Forest Garden, a new, greenfield, 1 acre site.

item.title: Most attractive fruit colours to birds
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: In descending order of attractiveness: Purple Red Orange Black (mulberries) Not sure where Martin Crawford sourced this information from.

item.title: Condensed forest garden knowledge
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I happened to be passing Farmyard Nurseries (where I accidentally bought some Mentha longifolia) and met someone who wants to start a forest garden.

item.title: The seven layers of a forest garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: @AgroforestryT has a definition of forest gardening and helpfully lists the “seven layers” of a forest garden:

item.title: How to plant & mulch a weedy windbreak
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: We’ve planted Amelanchier canadensis, Elaeagnus umbellata, Berberis darwinii and Viburnum opulus in the northern double-width windbreak hedge of the Ornamental Forest Garden.

item.title: The joy of forest garden planning
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Things have started happening in the Ornamental Forest Garden—we have the beginnings of a Northern Hedge, the plants from ScotPlants Direct are arriving tomorrow, and the digger cometh.

item.title: Forest garden thug or doer?
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Some plants in the garden if left to their own devices will just take over, bramble (Rubus fruticosus) being an excellent example.

item.title: Windbreak hedges for an exposed coastal site
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: At last Saturday’s pruning workshop by The People’s Orchard I was talking with some people from Fishguard.

item.title: Forest Garden Network
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: The Forest Garden Network is a free and informal network of forest gardeners and agroforestry practitioners, administered by Martin Crawford from the Agroforestry Research Trust.

item.title: I know nothing
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: The People’s Orchard hosted a fantastically well attended pruning workshop on Saturday 26th January (about 27 people).

item.title: Three ways to describe a forest garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: It’s always handy to have some simple forest garden definitions to hand. A forest garden is:

item.title: The place you want to be
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Sarah Price gave a magnificent talk for the Inspirational Women in Horticulture series, tracing her professional career as a garden designer, whilst simultaneously stimulating key questions about what and how a garden is and does.

item.title: The forest garden in midwinter
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Looking forward to the spring, I’m running our first forest garden tours and workshops.

item.title: Your small garden can be a forest garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: One drawback with forest gardening is the name. Firstly, it emulates the edge of a woodland, not the deepest, darkest depths of a forest.

item.title: Inspirational women (some of them in horticulture)
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I’m a latecomer to the gardening party and I sometimes feel like a gatecrasher, inadvertently swept in on the coat-tails of forest gardening (you know, the scruffy one with the wild look in its eye).

item.title: Now taking bookings for forest garden tours and workshops
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Our 2019 workshops and tours are now available to book on Airbnb: Forest garden workshop Forest garden tour Both available from April through to September 2019 The tour is 2 hours, available in two slots 10am-12pm & 2pm-4pm The workshop is 6 hours, 10am-4pm It has been an interesting experience (ahem) to go through the Airbnb application process.

item.title: Creating a forest garden in 8 easy steps
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: We started creating a forest garden about 3 years ago. I always recommend people thoroughly read Creating a Forest Garden by Martin Crawford.

item.title: Gardening like a child
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I had planned to put up some chicken wire on the bottom of the gates to stop @ForestGdnDog from running out in the road.

item.title: The forest garden: it’s about time
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: It started with a tweet by @AmielWayne : What a lovely 😊 idea, instead of a traditional Christmas card, a friend from the Antipodes has spent me a mini Calendar of beautiful Australia Wildflowers @australian @AusHCUK #wildflowers pic.

item.title: Cream-crackered lime
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: There’s a metric tonne of powdered lime in the Dutch Barn that needs to make way for the annual thinning of the 2 acre woodland.

item.title: Mulching raised beds
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Someone on @GdnBloggers recommended Ruth Stout’s No Work Garden Book, and it has been a true delight, full of little mulching nuggets of practical wisdom.

item.title: Gardening with urgency and purpose
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I am not a natural born gardener. I’ve come to it late, initially provoked by the threat of climate change and tantalised by the prospect of a productive, low maintenance, wildlife friendly forest garden.

item.title: Gardener’s log, start date 2018-12-20
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I’ve been inspired by Alison Levey @papaver’s blog the blackberry garden. It is full of detail, about things as they happen.

item.title: Deturfing the Greenery
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Last week I decided to grow more greens in a dedicated Greenery area. Today, the lofty plans came crashing down into muddy grunt work.

item.title: Sea Buckthorn planted in Willow Walk
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I bought two Hippophae rhamnoides (Sea Buckthorn) ‘Orange Energy’ from Agroforestry Research Trust. They’re one of the few native nitrogen fixing trees/shrubs (I can only think of Cytisus scoparius (Broom) off-hand but I’m sure there are others).

item.title: Where to store your garden blog photos
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Back in the day, I used WordPress to write my blog and moreover used it to upload all my worthy garden photos.

item.title: ‘Miniature Woodlands’ at Chelsea Flower Show
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: Very interesting news article in the @Telegraph by Helena Horton @horton_official, entitled ‘Miniature woodlands’ which help beat pollution set to overshadow traditional gardens at Chelsea Flower Show.

item.title: My first ever paid forest garden design job
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I’m proud to have finished my first paid forest garden design. It was a remote job, which I chanced upon via Facebook.

item.title: Now is the best time for hardwood cuttings
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: The best time for hardwood cuttings is from mid-autumn until late winter. Kind of round about now.

item.title: The surveying legwork of the Ornamental #ForestGarden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: “Never mind surveying the forest garden plot, my plants are arriving this afternoon!

item.title: A forest garden is a way to garden
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: I listened to the Margaret Roach podcast A Way to Garden, the episode entitled “Go ahead, we dare you: widen your plant palette”, with Andy Brand.

item.title: I’ve had enough, it’s time to quit!
item.author: hello@growdigital.org (Jake Rayson)
item.description: For the past 3 years I’ve been leading a double life. By day, a jolly Forest Gardener.
